qas.question: What Indian thinkers were early idealists?
What Greek philosophers had idealistic views?
With what sect of Buddhism was the Yogācāra school affiliated?
In what century did the Yogācāra school arise?
What century did George Berkeley live in?
When did the Yogacara school end?
What type of Buddhism was common in Greece?
What practice where Neoplatonists arguing against?

context: The earliest extant arguments that the world of experience is grounded in the mental derive from India and Greece. The <a0_0>Hindu<a0_0/> idealists in India and the Greek <a1_0>Neoplatonists<a1_0/> gave panentheistic arguments for an all-pervading consciousness as the ground or true nature of reality. In contrast, the Yogācāra school, which arose within <a2_0><b8_0>Mahayana<b8_0/><a2_0/> Buddhism in India in the <a3_0><b5_0>4th<a3_0/> century CE<b5_0/>, based its "mind-only" idealism to a greater extent on phenomenological analyses of personal experience. This turn toward the subjective anticipated empiricists such as <b6_0>George Berkeley<b6_0/>, who revived idealism in <a4_0><b7_0>18th<a4_0/>-century<b7_0/> Europe by employing skeptical arguments against <b9_0>materialism<b9_0/>.
